author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Yang and Garcia Form Late Alliance in Mayor’s Race, Drawing Adams’s Ire
description: Andrew Yang and Kathryn Garcia campaigned together on Saturday in a show of unity that their top rival, Eric Adams, sought to portray as racially motivated.
content: Andrew Yang and Kathryn Garcia, two leading candidates in the New York City mayor’s race, joined each other on the campaign trail on Saturday, a late alliance that the contest’s front-runner, Eric Adams, immediately sought to portray as an attempt to weaken the voice of minority voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: E-Cards Are Back, Thanks to the Pandemic
description: The popularity of virtual cards has grown again as people sought ways to connect with loved ones and friends in the isolation and separation of Covid-19 restrictions.
content: Nearly a generation after the electronic postcard was introduced, digital greeting cards experienced an increase in demand last year as the pandemic isolated people from their social circles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinne Purtill
title: How Public Letters Became Companies’ Favorite Form of Activism
description: Chief executives have signed countless statements in support of social causes over the last few years. Do they make a difference?
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser and Jenny Gross
title: Scottish Man Who Faked His Death in California Is Jailed for Rape
description: The man’s son told the authorities that his father drowned. Months later, he was found in Colorado and extradited to Scotland, where he was sentenced to 15 years in prison.
content: It is not uncommon for the police to receive calls about people in distress at Monastery Beach in California — known locally as Mortuary Beach because of its deadly undertow and steep drop into the ocean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: As France Sends U.S. a Second Statue of Liberty, Her Symbolism is Debated
description: The statue and a reproduction of her French sculptor’s model will stand close to each other, just as some are asking whose freedom she celebrates.
content: PARIS — At the Museum of Arts and Crafts, not one of the premier tourist venues in Paris, in the subdued light of a former church, stands the plaster model for the Statue of Liberty. Made in 1878 by the French sculptor Frédéric-Auguste Bartholdi, eight years before Lady Liberty’s inauguration in New York Harbor, it represents the first full imagining of what would become, for many but not all, a paramount icon of freedom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Tropical Storm Claudette Spawns Tornadoes and Brings Heavy Rains to the South
description: The storm, which was downgraded to a depression on Saturday afternoon, brought tornadoes to portions of Alabama, Florida, Georgia and Mississippi.
content: Tropical Storm Claudette, the third named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season, formed in the Gulf of Mexico and brought “copious rainfall” of five to 10 inches across the Mississippi Delta and Gulf Coast before being downgraded to a tropical depression on Saturday, forecasters said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Farnaz Fassihi
title: For Biden, Iranian Hard-liner May Be Best Path to Restoring Nuclear Deal
description: The next six weeks before a new government takes office in Tehran may be a unique window for clinching an agreement that Iran’s leadership has been delaying.
content: WASHINGTON — Iran’s announcement on Saturday that an ultraconservative former head of the judiciary, Ebrahim Raisi, has been elected president now touches off an unpredictable diplomatic drama: The ascension of a hard-line government in Iran may actually present the Biden administration with a brief opportunity to restore the 2015 nuclear deal with the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: French police clash with hundreds at rave that violated a curfew.
description: Five officers were also injured in violent clashes that erupted on Friday night in the town of Redon, in Brittany.
content: PARIS — Violent clashes erupted on Friday night between hundreds of partygoers and police officers trying to break up an illegal rave in western France, leaving several people injured on both sides, including one man whose hand was severed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: Los Angeles Just Elected a Liberal D.A. He’s Already Facing a Recall Effort.
description: George Gascón is facing an intense backlash for enacting the sorts of policies demanded by protesters after the killing of George Floyd.
content: LOS ANGELES — From inside the walls of Folsom State Prison, the two inmates, one a convicted murderer, clinked their cups of prison moonshine in a toast to the new district attorney of Los Angeles, George Gascón.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: A Roadblock for Iran’s President-Elect: He’s on the U.S. Sanctions List
description: Ebrahim Raisi, who is accused of grave human rights violations, has also been penalized by the European Union.
content: At a 2019 rally for commanders of Iran’s powerful Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, Ebrahim Raisi, the conservative head of the country’s judicial system at the time, vowed to dismember corrupt Iranians and praised the Guards for shooting down an American drone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: The Big Tuna Sandwich Mystery
description: A lawsuit against America’s largest sandwich chain has raised questions about America’s most popular canned fish. We tried to answer one: Is Subway selling tuna?
content: Canned tuna is high in protein, low in fat and by far the most popular shelf-stable seafood in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Autocrats Use London Courts to Batter Enemies
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 19, 2021.
content: “We can’t allow ourselves to be used as a pawn in a bigger game.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Janet Malcolm, a Writer Who Emphasized the Messiness of Life With Slyness and Precision
description: The longtime staff writer for The New Yorker, who died on Wednesday at 86, was most animated by divided selves and the inherent complexity of human relationships.
content: Whenever I would begin to read anything by Janet Malcolm, my expectations were split in two: a soothing sense that it would be confidently and exactingly written, paired with an apprehension — an almost exquisite dread — of the startling truths it was bound to reveal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jaime Lowe
title: ‘If You Move Out Here, You Make a Deal With Nature’: Life in a Fire-Prone Canyon
description: Topanga Canyon in Los Angeles County, home to both fire preppers and the fire fatigued, is a scenic, isolated world that has turned the threat of catastrophe into an everyday norm.
content: TOPANGA, Calif. — The Palisades Fire that forced hundreds to evacuate last month on the outskirts of Los Angeles never got close to James Grasso’s house. But he watched it carefully from the hilltops in Topanga Canyon in the Santa Monica Mountains, with his emergency radios and pagers by his side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: ‘I’m Getting Ready’: Football Star’s Cryptic Video Could Upend Georgia Senate Race
description: If the Georgia college football legend Herschel Walker declares his candidacy it could put former President Donald J. Trump’s power as a kingmaker to the test.
content: ATLANTA — In his 1980s prime, Herschel Walker, the Georgia college football legend, ran the ball with the downhill ferocity of a runaway transfer truck. There was no question about which way he was headed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: With Billions of Dollars at Stake, a Critical Race Vies for Attention
description: Candidates to be New York City’s next chief financial officer are straining for attention from the public during a crucial moment.
content: One candidate, Brad Lander, landed a potent one-two political punch: the coveted endorsement of Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and a successful campaign ad using the time-honored strategy of deploying one’s child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: ‘Disorder and Chaos’ in N.Y.C. Jails as Pandemic Recedes
description: Six incarcerated people have died, a man accused of murder was accidentally released and a captain was charged with criminally negligent homicide, while the future of Rikers Island remains unclear.
content: Violence on Rikers Island is surging. Exhausted guards are working triple shifts. And staffing shortages have triggered lockdowns at some of the jail’s largest facilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Something Released While Skydiving
description: Sophia Maymudes makes her Saturday debut, solo, without a net.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This grid has a perfect set of bookends, starting and finishing a very tongue-in-cheek set of clues by recent college grad Sophia Maymudes, who makes her Saturday and solo themeless debut. (In fact, this is Ms. Maymudes’s first solo Times puzzle since her memorably witty first effort, which was a themed Thursday.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Pope’s Silence Speaks Volumes on Controversial Communion Vote by U.S. Bishops
description: The divergence of the conservative American church from Francis’ agenda is now so obvious as to be unremarkable, even when U.S. bishops ignore a Vatican warning.
content: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis on Saturday put a founder of the European Union on the track to sainthood, told Roman deacons to take care of the poor and met with a top prelate who once defended him against wild allegations by the Vatican’s former ambassador to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Rothfeld, Joseph Goldstein, Ashley Southall and Michael Wilson
title: ‘Keep an Eye on This Guy’: Inside Eric Adams’s Complicated Police Career
description: Mr. Adams’s police credentials have helped him rise to the top of this year’s mayoral field. But his relationship with the department is complex.
content: As Eric Adams lined up for graduation at the New York City Police Academy in 1984, he congratulated the cadet who had beaten him out for valedictorian, only to learn that the other recruit’s average was a point lower than his own. Mr. Adams complained to his commander about the slight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: College Baseball Player in Virginia Dies After Joint Surgery
description: Sang Ho Baek, 20, “had been battling injuries throughout the season,” a teammate said, and underwent Tommy John surgery, a relatively common procedure for pitchers.
content: A college baseball player died from complications of a surgery shortly after completing his freshman season at George Mason University in Virginia, according to the school and a funeral home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: Vintage Vases Find New Life as Bongs
description: Two trends in one: Upcycled antique glassware and marijuana accessories.
content: Kat Briceno, 34, has been smoking marijuana for years but didn’t own a bong until 2017, when they converted an antique vase into a smoking device. (Mx. Briceno uses the pronouns they and them.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and Maria Cramer
title: Police Shoot Driver Who Struck Cyclists at Arizona Bike Race
description: Six people were seriously injured when a man driving a pickup truck plowed into cyclists at a bike race in Show Low, Ariz., the police said. The driver was then shot and wounded by the police.
content: The driver of a pickup truck hit a group of cyclists at a bicycle race in Show Low, Ariz., on Saturday, seriously injuring six people before the driver fled and was shot by the police, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times and Aidan Gardiner
title: Scenes From Juneteenth: America’s Newest Holiday, 156 Years in the Making
description: From Brooklyn to Galveston, there were scenes of joy and reflections on the meaning of the holiday. “We have to celebrate that we survived,” one man said.
content: Standing at the site in Galveston, Texas, where on June 19, 1865, a Union general signed an order notifying enslaved African Americans that they were free, the artist Reginald C. Adams marveled at the moment he found himself in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: For Richard Bland, the 478th Try Was a Charm. Now He’s at the U.S. Open.
description: The 48-year-old English golfer, whose first tour victory came last month, shared the lead after two rounds of the Open at Torrey Pines.
content: SAN DIEGO — For 25 years, Richard Bland of England wondered if he might forever view his golf career with “the disappointment of slightly underachieving.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon send us down the middle of the road with a timely toughie.
content: ACROSTIC — This Sunday is Father’s Day, and today’s quotation is a famous musician's reminiscence about her early years and her dad’s influence. The musician is Chrissie Hynde and the excerpt is from her 2016 memoir, called “Reckless: My Life as a Pretender.” I assume you’re familiar with the Pretenders, who formed in 1978 and are still making music and touring; there’s an additional reference in the puzzle to another musician whose own memoir was featured in the acrostic earlier this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Friedman
title: The Failed Promise of the Aerobics Revolution
description: A new dramedy on Apple TV+ explores the roots of America's fitness craze.
content: Revolutions don’t always happen in the streets. In the early 1980s, a seismic shift took place in strip-mall storefronts that smelled of sweat and Enjoli. Pulsing to the beat of Donna Summer and glistening with spandex, these fluorescent-lit rooms vibrated with the energy of career women and housewives bouncing in unison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Rising From Pandemic, New York Seeks a New Mayor to Face Looming Crises
description: Eric Adams is considered the front-runner in Tuesday’s Democratic primary, but the race is fluid enough that another candidate may win.
content: The New York City mayor’s race began in the throes of a pandemic, in a shuttered city convulsed by a public health catastrophe, economic devastation and widespread protests over police brutality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: My 70-Year-Old Father Joined Tinder
description: What seemed like a nightmare scenario turned out to be a new way to bond.
content: Until recently, if you had asked me about the prospect of my dad remarrying, my response would have verged on the murderous. I never saw him as a guy who dated, let alone a guy who dated online. But then my mom died in the fall of 2018, and there he was, alone. Alone, and eventually, on Tinder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Champ, the Bidens’ German Shepherd, Dies at 13
description: Champ, who was the family’s cherished companion, “died peacefully at home,” President Biden and the first lady said.
content: Champ, a German shepherd who helped restore the time-honored presidential tradition of having a pet at the White House, died on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Koczwara
title: Gerald Stratford Knows How to Garden
description: His quiet life in England brought fame. He wasn’t asking for it.
content: Gerald Stratford’s big vegetables and ordinary life changed with a tweet. He posted two pictures of himself wearing a red T-shirt and matching pants held up by thick blue suspenders in May 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
title: How Republican States Are Expanding Their Power Over Elections
description: In Georgia, Republicans are removing Democrats of color from local boards. In Arkansas, they have stripped election control from county authorities. And they are expanding their election power in many other states.
content: LaGRANGE, Ga. — Lonnie Hollis has been a member of the Troup County election board in West Georgia since 2013. A Democrat and one of two Black women on the board, she has advocated Sunday voting, helped voters on Election Days and pushed for a new precinct location at a Black church in a nearby town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joel Stein
title: The Subscription Box That Teaches Kids to Do Good
description: What is a liberal, atheist parent to do if you want to raise volunteers?
content: Like all fathers, what I want for Father’s Day is to be lied to. I want my 12-year-old son, Laszlo, to make me a card telling me that I instilled values in him. Preferably with a drawing of me doing something noble, such as solving the conflict in the Middle East, though I’m not exactly sure how he’d draw that. I’m also not sure how I would have instilled those values.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Perriello
title: Some Catholic Leaders Deserve to Have Biden’s Ear, and Some Do Not
description: The efforts by conservative bishops to arbitrate who receives communion reinforce why the American bishops so often stand alone.
content: The last time I took communion was in El Salvador, not long before the pandemic. As a Catholic, I enjoy exploring how Mass is experienced and enriched by different cultures. But I had a more urgent reason for searching out this ritual abroad. It provided my only chance to take the Eucharist, because I quietly decided 10 years ago that I could not in good conscience do so under the auspices of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops.
source.name: The New York Times

title: To the Grill!
description: Grab the charcoal. You’re making grilled chicken, grilled tofu or skewers this weekend.
content: Summer is nearly here, and the best way to commemorate its arrival is by charring something over a hot flame. Get your grill marks on with Melissa Clark’s za’atar chicken with garlic yogurt and cilantro , Kay Chun’s perfectly striped grilled tofu or Naz Deravian’s joojeh kabab ba holu, browned and juicy saffron chicken kababs with peaches (above). And our most popular recipe of the week, Hetty McKinnon’s tzatziki potato salad, would look great alongside any of those.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: An Old Yankees Draft Pick Comes Back to Haunt Them
description: James Kaprielian continued a strong start for red-hot Oakland. The Mets, meanwhile, lost a nail-biter to Washington.
content: James Kaprielian finally made it to the Bronx, six years after the Yankees took him in the first round of the amateur draft, and he beat his original club by pitching three-hit ball over five and two-thirds innings in a 5-3 victory Friday night that extended the Oakland Athletics’ winning streak to seven.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Video of Montreal Police Kneeling on Black Teenager Spurs Outcry
description: Outrage over the video comes as Canada undergoes a national awakening about institutional racism, including among police forces.
content: MONTREAL — For some Canadians, the 90-second video evoked memories of George Floyd: A white police officer appears to be kneeling on the neck of a Black teenager who is face down on the ground on a Montreal street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Two Men Blocking Military Sexual Assault Reform
description: The military justice system is in dire need of an overhaul. Two senators are standing athwart a bipartisan fix.
content: These days, it is tough to get a supermajority of U.S. senators to agree on the color of the sky, much less a politically delicate piece of legislation. Yet this is precisely what is happening with the Military Justice Improvement and Increasing Prevention Act, a bill championed by Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, the New York Democrat, that would overhaul how the armed services handle accusations of rape, sexual assault and other serious crimes. In addition to beefing up training and prevention, the proposal would shift the decision to prosecute many felonies “from the chain of command to independent, trained, professional military prosecutors.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Rent Relief Has Arrived. Here’s How Landlords and Tenants Can Claim It.
description: A new rent assistance fund began accepting applications this month, making it a good time for landlords to start communications with their tenants.
content: Q: I own a small rental property in Queens. The tenants in one apartment owe me several months of rent, and have not made any attempts to set up a payment plan. So long as the eviction moratorium is in place, my hands are tied. But I can’t afford the legal fees that it would cost to bring an eviction case against them — I’ve depleted my savings keeping up on the mortgage, taxes and other costs of running a building. Now that rent relief is available, would they qualify? Would I see the money if they did?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Frances Stein, a Fashion Force at Chanel and Elsewhere, Dies at 83
description: Halston hired her to design his first collections. She worked with Calvin Klein. And she helped make Chanel newly relevant when it was floundering in the 1970s.
content: Frances Stein, who was a fashion editor, a fashion muse and a designer for Halston and Calvin Klein before helping to revive the house of Chanel, died on June 6 at her apartment in Paris. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Vecsey
title: A Dad and an Audience of One
description: I had to share my father with millions of readers, but they never got to hear the back stories over a Wendy’s hamburger coming home from Shea Stadium in the middle of the night.
content: Our house often mimicked the sounds of a newsroom: the rustling of the paper over morning coffee; the ringing of phones; the pounding of a heavy black Royal typewriter, each volley of keystrokes followed by a ding and the slap of the carriage return; and then the dictation of that day’s copy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zoë Lescaze
title: A History of Getting Hammered, and Why Some of Us Should Keep Doing It
description: In “Drunk,” Edward Slingerland plays devil’s advocate for the pleasure and utility of Dionysian abandon.
content: DRUNK How We Sipped, Danced, and Stumbled Our Way to Civilization By Edward Slingerland
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: Ryan Lochte Fails to Make U.S. Olympic Swim Team
description: At age 36, Lochte tried to make the team for the fifth time, five years after his turn at the 2016 Games was marred by his false claim about being robbed at gunpoint.
content: OMAHA — They formed a receiving line as if at a wake, celebrating Ryan Lochte one last time at the U.S. Olympic trials Friday night after his long swimming career appeared to die of natural causes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Familiar Surroundings
description: You’ll have to look within to solve Michael Lieberman’s Sunday debut.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — It has been awhile since we’ve seen a good old-fashioned Sunday brain twister; they’re fun, and vital to the rotation. Michael Lieberman, a Washington, D.C., appellate attorney, is currently on parental leave for his first baby, so we’ll call this his first Father’s Day puzzle. He has already constructed three Monday and Tuesday grids for The Times. Those early-week puzzles lend themselves to the kind of mind that comes up with a challenge like we have before us — a light, fun theme that I still managed to trip over a few times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: A 14-Year-Old Bride, Wed to Her Rapist, Playing on a Jungle Gym
description: The United States has fought against child marriage around the world. Let’s do the same at home.
content: For years, the United States has campaigned against child marriage around the world, from Guatemala to Zimbabwe. But we should listen to ourselves: Forty-five states here in America continue to allow girls and boys under 18 to wed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni and Ernesto Londoño
title: Brazil, Besieged by Covid, Now Faces a Severe Drought
description: Brazilians are paying more for electricity, dealing with the possibility of water rationing and expecting a destructive fire season in the Amazon in the worst dry spell in at least 90 years.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Crops have shriveled up under searing heat. Immense water reservoirs, which generate the bulk of Brazil’s electricity, are growing alarmingly shallow. And the world’s largest waterfall system, Iguaçu Falls, has been reduced from a torrent to a trickle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Singapore allows Sinovac shots, but casts doubt on their effectiveness.
description: Singapore is allowing 24 private health clinics to administer the vaccine. But it has not added it to the national vaccination program.
content: Some people in Singapore began receiving the Covid vaccine manufactured by the Chinese company Sinovac at private clinics on Friday, even as one of the city-state’s top health officials cast doubt on its effectiveness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Inside the ‘Deadly Serious’ World of E-Sports in South Korea
description: Each year, thousands of young South Koreans compete to join pro e-sports teams, but only a few make the cut​. An American company in Seoul wants to help more young gamers find jobs.
content: SEOUL — The students ate lunch in silence before gathering in a dimly lit room packed with high-powered computers. There, coaches helped them learn to outmaneuver opponents in a digital fantasy world fraught with ambushes and monsters. School was over by 5 p.m., but individual practice continued well into the night — all in a hard day’s work for the students at one of South Korea’s many e-sports academies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Does the Perfect ‘MLBB’ Lipstick Exist?
description: As the masks come off, the search for the perfect “my lips but better” shade continues, perhaps into perpetuity.
content: The most time-honored beauty tips involve some degree of pain: Bite your lips until they redden, or scrub them with a toothbrush, or pinch your fingertips or cheeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: As Money Launderers Buy Dalís, U.S. Looks at Lifting the Veil on Art Sales
description: Secrecy has long been part of the art market’s mystique, but now lawmakers say they fear it fosters abuses and should be addressed.
content: The federal agents who raided a drug dealer’s house in a suburb of Philadelphia found marijuana and, to their surprise, $2.5 million in cash stashed in a secret compartment beneath a fish tank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Annie Karni
title: The United States sends 2.5 million doses of Moderna’s vaccine to help Taiwan battle its first major outbreak.
description: The shipment, to arrive on Sunday, is triple what the U.S. had pledged. It may irk China.
content: The United States is shipping 2.5 million doses of Moderna’s Covid-19 vaccines to Taiwan on Saturday, tripling the original amount the Biden administration had promised, Ned Price, the State Department spokesman, said in a tweet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Sean Piccoli
title: 2 Children Out Walking Get Caught Between a Gunman and His Target
description: The harrowing scene in the Bronx, captured on surveillance video, came about a week after a 10-year-old Queens boy was fatally shot.
content: Gunfire erupts on a Bronx sidewalk, and several passers-by, including a 5-year-old boy and his 10-year-old sister, rush toward a bodega’s entrance for shelter. But the children collide with a man who is also racing for cover, and all three fall to the pavement before finding safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Edward Diener, Psychologist Known as Dr. Happiness, Dies at 74
description: Since the 1980s, he was recognized as a leader in measuring what he called “subjective well-being.” And, yes, he was very happy.
content: Edward Diener, a playful social psychologist who was nicknamed Dr. Happiness for his pioneering research into what defined contentment, died on April 27 at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Judge Blocks C.D.C. From Enforcing Virus Rules for Cruise Ships in Florida
description: The decision was a victory for Florida, which had argued that the rules were crippling the cruise industry and causing the state to lose hundreds of millions of dollars.
content: A federal judge ruled on Friday that, beginning on July 18, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will no longer be allowed to enforce its rules intended to prevent the spread of the coronavirus on cruise ships in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: Departure of U.S. Contractors Poses Myriad Problems for Afghan Military
description: It is not just U.S. troops who are withdrawing from Afghanistan. Thousands of private contractors — who help keep the Afghan Air Force flying, among other tasks — are leaving as well.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — An Afghan Air Force UH-60 Black Hawk helicopter, shelled while on the ground by the Taliban on Wednesday, sat helpless at a small outpost in the country’s southeast, its burning and damaged airframe displayed in a video on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Strange Death of Liberal Russophobia
description: How the Biden presidency is (wisely) opting out of Cold War 2.0.
content: Last August, I predicted that Donald Trump’s electoral defeat would encourage a lot of Republican politicians to embrace Don Draper’s mantra from “Mad Men,” his explanation of how easy it is to bury an inconvenient piece of your own past: “This never happened. It will shock you how much it never happened.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Iranian Hard-Liner Ebrahim Raisi Wins Presidential Vote
description: The government announced his victory on Saturday, a day after a vote that many Iranians skipped, viewing it as rigged.
content: TEHRAN — After many Iranians skipped voting in Friday’s presidential election, seeing it as rigged in favor of an ultraconservative contender, that candidate — the hard-line judiciary chief, Ebrahim Raisi — won Iran’s presidency on Saturday, paving the way for the country’s leadership to cement the conservative legacy of the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Your Guide to Voting in New York’s Mayoral Primary
description: What you should know about casting your ballot if you still want to do it early or are heading to the polls on Tuesday.
content: After a campaign season full of Zoom forums, television ads and fliers stuffed in mailboxes, voting in New York City’s municipal primary has begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Cramer
title: Leave This Wondrous Island to the Birds
description: An ever-changing spit of sand on the Carolina coast is a haven for multitudes of shorebirds. But nature and humans threaten it.
content: An ever-changing spit of sand on the Carolina coast is a haven for multitudes of shorebirds. But nature and humans threaten it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Storyful
title: Scenes of Flooding From Tropical Storm Claudette
description: After forming on Saturday in the Gulf of Mexico, the storm dropped several inches of rain in the Mississippi Delta and along the Gulf Coast. Tornadoes were reported in Alabama, Florida, Georgia and Mississippi.
content: After forming on Saturday in the Gulf of Mexico, the storm dropped several inches of rain in the Mississippi Delta and along the Gulf Coast. Tornadoes were reported in Alabama, Florida, Georgia and Mississippi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: U.N. Condemns Myanmar Military Over Coup
description: The United Nations General Assembly adopted a resolution on Friday rebuking the Myanmar military and demanding an end to its five-month-old coup.
content: The United Nations General Assembly adopted a resolution on Friday rebuking the Myanmar military and demanding an end to its five-month-old coup.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Conflicts Within the A.C.L.U. Over Free Speech and Racial Justice
description: Readers react to an article about turmoil at the organization as progressives question its defense of offensive speech as a First Amendment right.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 19, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 19, 2021.
content: An article on Friday about a space launch in China referred incorrectly to senior political and military leaders who watched the launch on Thursday. Some were in Beijing; not all were at the space launch center near Jiuquan.
source.name: The New York Times
